clean_story:
Unmatched intellect. No guidance.

An orphaned genius is a person of extraordinary talent who lacks the support—family, mentors, or resources—to fully develop their potential.

Most child prodigies have parents or teachers pushing them forward.
But imagine a chess master at 8, solving equations at 10, yet sleeping on park benches.
History holds cases like Srinivasa Ramanujan, a self-taught mathematician from poverty in India.
He scribbled theorems on scraps of paper, unaware his work would later rewrite number theory.
Or George Boole, raised by a shoemaker, who invented Boolean algebra—the foundation of modern computers—while teaching himself from borrowed books.

Without structure, their minds become both their tool and their trap.
Some burn out.
Others, like Terence Tao—though not orphaned—show how early nurturing accelerates breakthroughs.
The difference? A desk. A mentor. A meal.

Lost potential.
Untapped equations.
The cost of a system that only rewards visible genius.

Autodidacts.
Childhood trauma and creativity.
Systems that fail the exceptional.
